trustfund: TF033899-EAST ASIA - MEKONG BASIN,TF032984-EAST ASIA - MEKONG BASIN FINANCING,TF031215-CAMBODIA - SOCIAL FUND,TF025995-EMERGENCY REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF029162-PHRD-SOCIAL FUND PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF029233-PHRD-SOCIAL FUND PROJECT (RECIPIENT-EXEC.)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project was satisfactory, with
            sustainable likelihood, and substantial institutional
            development impacts. The Bank's performance was highly
            satisfactory, primarily due to an outstanding supervision,
            which provided corrective actions as needed, supplemented by
            the findings of four technical assessments on project
            impacts, and beneficiary satisfaction. The Borrower's
            performance was satisfactory, with strong support at the
            highest level, evidenced by the speedy creation of the
            Social Fund Kingdom of Cambodia (SFKC), and effective
            preparation, and appraisal activities. Lessons stress the
            sustained efforts to ensure authentic community driven
            demand for subprojects, a challenge that proved successful
            in building partnerships with community organizations, and
            nongovernmental organizations, and in strengthening the
            participatory process. However, it would have been advisable
            for SFKC to develop a higher level of technical, and
            managerial skills, particularly as it regards counterpart
            resources, and maintenance costs, including careful
            selection of scale, and complexity of projects.
            Notwithstanding improvement procedures SFKC has developed to
            overcome delay problems, and quality of completed works,
            monitoring is paramount to ensure adherence to standards;
            thus, it would be useful for SFKC to implement a system of
            incentives tied to staff performance indicators.
            Furthermore, the issue of asset maintenance, is critical
            given the poverty status of most communities, and it is
            suggested that the role of local authorities be expanded to
            ensure program sustainability.
